awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: GEM--Thermal Electron Anisotropy in the Earth's Magnetotail
awd_abstract_narration:
One of the most important problems of space plasma physics is understanding how high-energy charged particles are generated. There are a huge variety of mechanisms suggested for accelerating electrons in the region of the geomagnetic field known as the current sheet. This project will help distinguish between these theories to help determine which are at work in the magnetosphere. This is directly relevant to the National Space Weather Plan, since the work can lead to better models and forecasts of space weather, which affects national commercial and defense satellites and space-based communications. Additionally, graduate and undergraduate students will participate in the research.

This project quantifies the impact of the electron thermal anisotropy on the magnetotail current sheet structure and investigates the variation of characteristics of electron thermal anisotropy with geomagnetic activity. The anisotropic electron population can be responsible for generation of strong currents (induced by particle curvature drifts) and can serve as an energy source for various electromagnetic wave emissions. The project uses observations from five spacecraft missions (Geotail, Cluster, THEMIS, ARTEMIS, and MMS) covering the entire magnetotail within the radial distances from 10 to 80 Earth radii downtail. Using several years of THEMIS/ARTEMIS observations in the near-Earth and middle magnetotail, the work studies both the radial distribution of the electron thermal anisotropy and the impact of electron anisotropic currents on current sheet structure for different magnetotail configurations. Moreover, using MMS observations with the high-resolution plasma measurements the work will for the first time statistically reveal the fine structure of the electron anisotropic population and its contribution to the current density.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The interaction between solar wind plasma and the Earth's magnetic field results in formation of the Earth's magnetotail, a plasma region on the night side dominated by strong plasma currents that is shown in the top panel of the attached figure. This project was focused on the analysis of the current density and thickness of the current layer in the Earth's magnetotail. The accurate analysis of these quantities is critical for understanding the force balance in the Earth's magnetotail as well as predicting and modelling substorms, the most energetic and powerful phenomena in the Earth's magnetosphere. Using THEMIS and Magnetospheric Multiscale measurements we determined the current density and thickness of the corresponding current layer at the radial distances from about 8 to 27 Earth radii from the Earth, that is the most critical region for the onset of substorms  

The main outcome of the project is the statistical analysis of the current layer and the revealed nature of the force-balance in the Earth's magnetotail. In the frame of the project we obtained the dependence of the thickness, current density and isotropic part of the plasma pressure on the radial distance from the Earth; for example, the bottom panel of the attached figure presents the thickness of the current layer in units of thermal proton gyroradius. The major finding is that the current layer is thinner and carries a larger current density than predicted by models assuming isotropic plasma pressure. In other words, the isotropic part of the observed plasma pressure has insufficiently large gradients to balance the tension of magnetic field lines. This is a strong and the most reliable indication that a substantial contribution into the current density in the Earth's magnetotail is provided by non-isotropic part of the plasma pressure, whose source is both electron anisotropy and ion non-gyrotropy. These results demonstrate that substorms are initiated in the current layer whose equilibrium structure and global configuration cannot be described by isotropic models widely used in the past. The future modelling of the Earth's magnetotail dynamics should take this critical fact into account. The results of the project have a broader impact, since similar current layers and substorm-like phenomena occur in other space and astrophysical environments (for example, solar flares).
